The control operator of the originating station is primarily responsible for any rule violation by their station, regardless of whether messages are being relayed or forwarded through intermediary systems. Answer A and C are incorrect because both the control operator of the packet bulletin board station and the control operators of other stations in the system do not have direct control over the content of messages originated by another station; while D could potentially share some responsibility for failing to verify the authenticity of incoming messages, it does not address primary responsibility for the original message's contents.

data.sampled:
B. 50 watts PEP effective radiated power relative to a dipole.

Explanation:
On the 60 meter amateur band, the maximum allowed power output is 50 Watts PEP (Peak Envelope Power), as measured relative to a dipole antenna. This means that the actual field strength of your signal at any given location may be higher or lower than this limit, depending on factors such as your specific transmitter and antenna combination. However, it is important to note that exceeding this limit can result in fines and other penalties under federal law. Therefore, it is essential to ensure that your transmissions remain within these legal limits when operating on the 60 meter ham band.

data.sampled:
B. A signal transmitted to prevent its detection by any station other than the intended recipient. 
This sounds like spread spectrum technology which is used in some forms of digital communications as well as military radar systems and satellite navigation networks such as GPS. 
The use of spread-spectrum technology avoids the need to worry about intentional or unintentional jamming; it also allows for more efficient use of bandwidth because a larger number of channels can be used. In addition, because there is no longer a fear of capture by an adversary, spread-spectrum technologies have become very popular in wireless networking applications such as Wireless Local Area Networks (WLANs), Bluetooth, Zigbee and many others. 
However, this definition does not exclude other possibilities so perhaps a better choice would be: D. An emission outside the signal's necessary bandwidth that can be reduced or eliminated without affecting the information transmitted. This describes an out of band emission but the answer could still be both C and D depending on your interpretation of "signal." The term 'spurious' suggests that the emissions were not part of the original signal but rather extraneous signals that somehow found their way into the system. However, since these signals do originate within the device itself - it could arguably fit under either category. I think this depends on whether you consider an unwanted sine wave coming off of a component within the device (such as switching supply or RF amplifier) that was always present but went undetected during design as being 'part of the signal.' If you don't then it fits into category C. But again, this could depend on how broadly or narrowly you want to define "signals." My guess is that either A, B or D would work depending on who you ask although my vote goes towards D.

B. They are restricted to 7.245 MHz, 14.245 MHz, 21.345 MHz, and 28.945 MHz.

Note: Slow-scan television (SSTV) is a mode of amateur radio communication in which images are transmitted over the air using amplitude modulation techniques at audio frequencies. The four specific frequencies mentioned (7.245 MHz, 14.245 MHz, 21.345 MHz, and 28.945 MHz) are designated as SSTV subbands within the larger amateur allocation at those frequencies. These bands have been set aside specifically for SSTV operation and are considered preferential frequencies for this mode. Operations outside these subbands may be subject to interference or conflicts with other modes, so it's important to follow established guidelines and best practices when operating SSTV.

data.sampled:
B. At the center frequency of the channel. This ensures that your CW transmission occupies as little bandwidth in the 15 meters and 60 meters bands as possible, which is important considering there are many other users trying to use those bands concurrently. Choosing a different frequency than the center would mean you could potentially interfere more with other transmissions, or create undue noise on them! In addition, choosing the lowest/highest frequencies means that your transmission has less distance over what it should cover, since its energy will not propagate fully throughout the entire channel allocated for amateur radio usage. Thus, the middle (center) frequency gives you optimal coverage without interfering too much with others, while also allowing you to receive signals as best as possible given natural transmission conditions such as weather, time of day, etcetera. Finally, note that when specifying frequencies we typically give them in MHz rather than kHz - so you should actually read this question as: What is the proper place for setting my transmitter's ___ MHz for legal 60m operations? Answer: The ____MHz point in the 60 meter band. That is, 5352kHz. If you prefer thinking about wavelength then the 5MHz point corresponds to approximately 49-54m in length for the relevant portion of the HF spectrum; or more generally between approximately 8 and 17 meters per megahertz (since wavelength = speed / frequency and the speed of light is constant, this distance gets longer as either the frequency increases OR the speed remains constant), so ~22m at 60MHz. But I hope now you understand why it's more common to work directly with the frequency numbers themselves instead of worrying too much about their physical representation here.

data.sampled:
B. Any FCC-issued amateur license. 

To be clear, this means any valid amateur radio license issued by the FCC will allow you to operate onboard your ship while it's sailing anywhere outside US territorial waters. It doesn't matter whether that license has the FCC marine endorsement mentioned as option A. You also don't need anything more advanced than Technician class privileges like option C specifies, and you certainly do not need a radiotelephone operator permit like D says. So long as you have any kind of currently active ham ticket issued by the FCC, you can transmit while at sea.

Of course, once your vessel crosses back into US territory, all bets are off. At that point, unless you possess both a valid amateur radio license plus one of two specific maritime endorsements--the FCC marine or aircraft endorsement--you cannot legally access the bands. This rule applies regardless of how close those inland waters might be; e.g., they could even constitute riverfront property along which your boat is temporarily docked. In short: no appropriate FCC credential = severe penalties + equipment seizure. Keep those details straight when planning out activities around US shores!

Hopefully, understanding these regulations will help you avoid accidental violations. Remember that deliberately flouting them risks fines and other punishments, so please respect whatever rules govern our shared airwaves. And if anyone needs additional guidance on how to obtain these specialized authorizations, I'm happy to provide further advice based on my own experiences getting the necessary paperwork processed through Washington DC. We can chat about that aspect during another session if desired. But until then, let me know if there's anything else I can assist with here!

data.sampled: B. 100 watts PEP. (Peak Envelope Power). This limit applies to all amateur radio bands. To pass your Technician Class license examination you need to know the specific limits applicable to the VHF and UHF bands used by repeaters and FM simplex operations as well as those for HF including 30 meters which was allocated in June 2022 for worldwide use by amateurs at up to 100 W PEP output on SSB/CW/Digital modes plus up to 75W PEP output on AM mode. There are no restrictions on antenna gain or type except that for all modes using more than 500w PEP input to the transmitter (i.e. all HF phone above 200W carrier power out) a 6dBi minimum front-to-back ratio is required, i.e., directional antennas must have substantially greater gain in the forward direction compared to the rearward direction. In contrast, on VHF and UHF bands there is usually a cap on ERP (Equivalent Radiated Power), the product of transmitter output power and antenna gain in dBi. On US bands between 50MHz and 470 MHz the cap is typically either 500mW + 6dBi (in most cases, e.g. FM and repeater operation) or 1kW + 6dBi (higher power mobile and handheld equipment). Different countries may have different rules for their allocations although there is generally close harmonization globally. Be sure to check before traveling internationally with your transceiver! Here's how to convert PEP to dBm: every increase of 3 decibels represents a doubling of power level; thus, -3

data.sampled:
B. 3 miles.

The correct answer can be found in the FCC regulations at Section 97.205(a), which states that "No amateur station shall cause harmful interference to any authorized radio communications." Additionally, Section 97.205(b) specifies that "An amateur station must accept any interference which may be caused by any other device or signal within its frequency band." Therefore, there is no specific distance requirement for an amateur station to protect an FCC monitoring facility from harmful interference; rather, the station's operator is required to ensure that their operation does not cause harmful interference and to accept any interference received on their operating frequency. It should also be noted that this applies specifically to monitoring stations used by the FCC for spectrum management purposes; the rules regarding protection of other types of facilities or services may differ.

The National Radio Quiet Zone covers two areas established by the Federal Communications Commission: one near the Green Bank Observatory in West Virginia and another near the Very Large Array radio telescope in New Mexico.[1][2] It was created to minimize interference to US government radio astronomical research at both observatories from other devices that transmit electromagnetic radiation in the radio frequency range, such as microwave ovens or motorized cars.[3]
